thread.title: Royal Caribbean's oldest ship headed to Port Canaveral
thread.title_full: Royal Caribbean's oldest ship headed to Port Canaveral

author: Richard Tribou
title: Royal Caribbean's oldest ship headed to Port Canaveral
text:
Royal Caribbean International Majesty of the Seas staying with Royal Caribbean and headed to Port Canaveral 
Royal Caribbean's oldest ship isn't going away after all, and it's coming to Port Canaveral with free Internet. 
The line announced Majesty of the Seas, which currently sails short itineraries from PortMiami, will come to the Central Florida port in summer 2016 while sending Rhapsody of the Seas to Tampa. 
At 74,077 tons, the Majesty of the Seas is dwarfed by Royal Caribbean's latest ships, the 168,666-ton, 4,180-passenger Quantum-class of ships. Caption Royal Caribbean Majesty of the Seas Royal Caribbean International The Royal Caribbean Majesty of the Seas first sailed in 1992 and will retire from the Royal Caribbean fleet in 2016. The Royal Caribbean Majesty of the Seas first sailed in 1992 and will retire from the Royal Caribbean fleet in 2016. (Royal Caribbean International) Caption Royal Caribbean Majesty of the Seas Royal Caribbean International The Royal Caribbean Majesty of the Seas first sailed in 1992 and will retire from the Royal Caribbean fleet in 2016. The Royal Caribbean Majesty of the Seas first sailed in 1992 and will retire from the Royal Caribbean fleet in 2016. (Royal Caribbean International) See more galleries 
Majesty of the Seas was to join its sister ships from years past, Sovereign of the Seas and Monarch of the Seas, by transferring from Royal Caribbean to Pullmantur cruise line, which is headquartered in Spain but sails many itineraries in the Caribbean catering to the Latin American market. That was announced in 2014, but demand prompted Royal Caribbean to reconsider. 
"Our short itineraries have been very popular offering vacationers the perfect opportunity to sample the unmatched experience of a Royal Caribbean cruise, as well as providing a quick adventurous getaway," said Royal Caribbean International President and CEO Michael Bayley.
